Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Intraoperative Lymphatic Mapping and Sentinel Node Biopsy in Early-Stage Melanoma

Trial_Design.evidence: Patients with primary cutaneous melanoma (≥1 mm with Clark level ≥III, or any thickness with Clark level ≥IV) were randomly assigned in a 4:6 ratio

Participants.evidence: Patients with primary cutaneous melanoma (≥1 mm with Clark level ≥III, or any thickness with Clark level ≥IV)

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned in a 4:6 ratio to wide excision (WE) plus observation (WEO) with delayed complete lymphadenectomy (CLND) for nodal recurrence, or to WE plus LM/SNB with immediate CLND for sentinel node (SN) metastasis

Objective.evidence: This international multicenter phase III trial aimed to evaluate the accuracy, use, and morbidity of intraoperative lymphatic mapping and sentinel node biopsy (LM/SNB) for staging regional nodal basins in early-stage melanoma.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the accuracy of LM/SNB, measured by SN identification rates and nodal metastases incidence, over a recruitment period ending March 31, 2002

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted after each center achieved 85% accuracy in SN identification during a 30-case learning phase.

Number_Randomised.evidence: over a recruitment period ending March 31, 2002, with 2001 patients enrolled

Result_Outcome.evidence: SN identification rate was 95.3% overall. False-negative LM/SNB rates decreased with increasing case volume: 10.3% for the first 25 cases versus 5.2% after 25 cases.

Harms.evidence: Complication rates were 10.1% for LM/SNB, increasing to 37.2% with CLND.

Trial_Registration.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.

Funding.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.
